Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Reoperation Techniques for Mitral Valve Repair Failure

Participants.evidence: 11 patients with moderately severe or severe mitral regurgitation due to recurrent prolapse after initial posterior leaflet repair with artificial chordae and annuloplasty at Cleveland Clinic

Intervention.evidence: Re-repair techniques included new, shorter artificial chordae (n=5), posterior leaflet resection (n=5), and new annuloplasty (n=8).

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates reoperation techniques for mitral valve repair failure.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the degree of mitral regurgitation post-reoperation, assessed by echocardiogram at discharge and follow-up (median 20 months).

Number_Randomised.evidence: 11 patients with moderately severe or severe mitral regurgitation due to recurrent prolapse after initial posterior leaflet repair with artificial chordae and annuloplasty at Cleveland Clinic from January 1, 2008, to January 31, 2023.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Ten patients underwent mitral valve re-repair, and one had valve replacement.

Result_Outcome.evidence: All patients had no or trace mitral regurgitation at discharge. At last follow-up, all had mild MR or less.

Harms.evidence: No operative mortality or major complications occurred.
